Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Security and Rights through the Advocacy of Women's Organizations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

Many women in post-conflict areas play a transformative role in formal and informal security, but they also must navigate the politics of UN Security Council resolutions regarding women's participation in post-conflict peacebuilding, national policies addressing women's security, and the politics and financial pressures of transnational NGOs. While there has been much interest in women's victimization and peacebuilding efforts, little attention has been directed to understanding how women holistically manage and advocate for their security in their communities. This project explores how individual and organizational narratives form a part of or potentially subvert dominant international discourses on women's roles and experiences in conflict as well as the relationship between women and peace. By prioritizing women's knowledge of their own security needs, this study contributes to efforts to improve U.S. foreign policy goals of women "as equal partners in preventing conflict and building peace." Ultimately, this study advances an understanding of how and to what extent international gender norms affect national policies and local implementation strategies, as well as how international policy-making in gender mainstreaming is fundamentally different from other types of security policy efforts.


Technical Summary

Specifically, this project addresses how local and national women's organizations in post-conflict areas of West Africa work to advocate for women's security. To do so, this study uses participant observation and interviews in Guinea and Mali (building on prior research in Cote d'Ivoire) to reveal how international resolutions impact local actions and also whether and how local women's priorities can shape international policies. Analyzing policies on women's security and the discourses that sustain them through macro-, meso-, and micro-level lenses will reveal how local and regional women's community organizations define their security goals and priorities, translate and localize the international agendas of the UN Security Council and transnational NGOs as well as the national agendas of governments, and work with local women to achieve peace and security. By examining the conflicts in Guinea and Mali, this project will develop a framework of how to understand women's needs in their communities and in national peacebuilding and reconstruction projects, underscoring that historical, political, and cultural contexts are important in developing successful, appropriate security policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many women in post-conflict areas play a transformative role in formal and informal security, but they also must navigate the politics of UN Security Council resolutions regarding women’s participation in post-conflict peacebuilding, national policies addressing women’s security (including the National Action Plans mandated by these resolutions), and the politics and financial pressures of transnational NGOs.

With the support of an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant, I conducted field research for three months each in Guinea and Mali. Specifically, I interviewed representatives of local women’s organizations working on peace and security, eight in each country. Additionally, I interviewed government officials in each country and representatives from UN Women and the UN Mission in Mali. In both countries, I also conducted participant observation with some of the local women’s organizations in their meetings, trainings, and workshops. The results in both countries largely coincided with prior field research I had conducted in Côte d'Ivoire.

Intellectual merits: My NSF research findings contribute to intellectual debates on UN effectiveness/peacebuilding/humanitarianism, the ability of women in post-conflict societies to advance sustainable peace, and what constitutes the primary concerns of women in post-conflict societies on the ground. Through my interviews, I found: First, local women’s organizations, in implementing the Women, Peace, and Security resolutions, must contend with two models of international intervention: a) a security/peacebuilding model that implements policies from the UN Security Council to the state to local actors to implement directives, and b) a development model that begins with international organizations to largely bypasses the state and directly fund local NGOs. Prior to these UN Security Council resolutions, women’s issues had usually been addressed as a development concern only. My research demonstrates that Security Council intervention, while important, produces a second model that conflicts with the first, resulting in a patchwork of policies that do not holistically address fundamental issues of women’s security. Moreover, I found that the effects of these two models differ between country contexts. In Mali, which is home to a peacekeeping mission and active conflict despite a two-year-old peace agreement, the two intervention mechanisms have equal effects, since peacebuilding programs that include women have been built on top of already-existing development structures. Guinea, by contrast, has never been home to a UN peacekeeping mission and has largely been off the radar of international security bodies. Therefore, most programs for women’s security are implemented through the processes of prior development projects, though with the language of security.

Second, my research contributes to scholarship on advancing peacebuilding in post-conflict societies, specifically the role of women in national contexts. I found that the national governments in both countries are essentially disengaged from women’s security and possible roles in peacebuilding, though they do pay lip service to “women’s unique characteristics” that they provide to society. I have found that the sidelining of women at the national level is partially because of lack of funding for women’s programs and because they are not seen as necessary to what the governments consider vital to state survival. In Mali, this is stability and controlling both inter-ethnic fighting and Islamic terrorism. In Guinea, this is also long-term stability and social cohesion, as well as attracting foreign capital investment. For both of these governments, women are not perceived as necessary to these projects and so women’s security and presence in politics and peacebuilding is a third-tier concern.

Finally, my research provides much-needed knowledge about how women in these societies understand their communities needs and how they implement directives in ways that sometimes subvert international policies. Women in Mali and Guinea both assume and counter the discourses told about them in international politics in a number of ways: skepticism, deployment of mothering roles, a broadening of what security means, and exercise of relationality beyond gender identity.

In the end, I conclude that women’s organizations are fundamentally responsible for implementation of the Women, Peace, and Security resolutions while at the same time being beholden to policymakers, governmental officials, and donors. Simultaneously, these organizations must manage others’ limited understandings of women’s lives in West Africa and cope with limited funding, leading to largely ineffective policy implementation.

The intellectual contributions of my NSF research are strongly related to its potential societal outcomes. Taking my research findings seriously entails reformulating policies in ways that a) build security from local women’s definitions and statements about their needs, rather from the United Nations and international organizations, and b) provide sufficient resources at the local level and incentives and resources at the national level in order to do so.
